brief_description of the content in the: The source URL describes a rule that identifies unnecessary '{@inheritDoc}' tags in Javadoc comments. The '{@inheritDoc}' tag is redundant if it's the only content in a Javadoc comment because Javadoc automatically inherits the super class's comment if no comment is present. The rule also identifies '{@inheritDoc}' tags in invalid locations, such as fields, and suggests removing the unnecessary Javadoc comment.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'unnecessary-inheritdoc' checks all classes and their methods and fields. If a method's Javadoc comment contains only '{@inheritDoc}', it asserts false and generates a message indicating the unnecessary '{@inheritDoc}' in the method of the class. Similarly, if a field's Javadoc comment contains '{@inheritDoc}', it asserts false and generates a message indicating the invalid '{@inheritDoc}' in the field of the class.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule appears to be syntactically correct according to the RSL syntax. It uses the built-in functions 'getClasses', 'getMethods', 'getFields', 'getDocComment', 'getName', and 'getFQN' to perform its checks.

1. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4593983/when-should-we-use-inheritdoc-in-java: This StackOverflow thread discusses the appropriate use of '{@inheritDoc}' in Java, which is relevant to the rule that identifies unnecessary '{@inheritDoc}' tags.
2. https://www.baeldung.com/javadoc: This Baeldung article provides a comprehensive guide to Javadoc, including the '{@inheritDoc}' tag. It explains how Javadoc comments are inherited, which is relevant to the rule's purpose of identifying unnecessary '{@inheritDoc}' tags.
